musicalLanguage.description: Written in 1954 as 'In Other Words', this became a jazz standard after Frank Sinatra's 1964 recording with Count Basie. The melody walks down the scale in a way that feels inevitable — each phrase landing on a chord tone that pulls you into the next change. It's a circle-of-fifths masterclass disguised as a love song.
musicalLanguage.structure: AABA form condensed into 16 bars. The A sections walk through the circle of fifths (Am-Dm-G-C), and the B section lifts to the IV chord before cycling back. Every phrase descends, giving the melody its characteristic graceful falling motion.
keyMoments: Measures 1-4: The opening descent Am7-Dm7-G7-Cmaj7 — a textbook ii-V-I preceded by vi. The melody falls stepwise through each chord.
Measures 5-8: Fmaj7-Bm7b5-E7-Am — the bridge lifts to IV, then the classic jazz iii-VI-ii turnaround. E7 to Am is the emotional pivot.
Measures 9-12: Second A — same changes, the melody varies slightly. Familiarity breeds comfort.
Measures 13-16: The final turnaround. Dm7-G7 resolving to C — home. The melody settles on the tonic with finality.
teachingGoals: Circle-of-fifths motion: Am-Dm-G-C (vi-ii-V-I). This is THE jazz progression. Once you hear it, you'll hear it everywhere.
Left hand shell voicings: root + 7th (or root + 3rd). These two-note voicings are the foundation of jazz piano comping.
Smooth melodic descent: the right hand moves mostly by step and small skip. Follow the line, don't jump.
The ii-V-I cadence (Dm7-G7-Cmaj7) — the most important progression in jazz. Practice this in all 12 keys.
Bm7b5 (half-diminished) — the diatonic iii chord in minor keys, functioning as ii in the key of Am. A beautiful, tense sound.
styleTips: Swing the eighth notes slightly — not dotted, just a gentle lean. Jazz lives in the space between straight and dotted.
Left hand should be quiet and steady. Think of it as a bassist walking underneath.
The melody should sing. Play legato, connect the notes. Imagine a vocalist phrasing each line.
Don't rush through the chord changes — let each one breathe. The beauty is in how they connect.
Dynamics: start mf, pull back to mp in the bridge, build back for the final resolution.

measures.teachingNote: Am7 — the vi chord. The melody descends C-B-A-G, all stepwise. Left hand: root-fifth shell. This opening descent is the song's signature — graceful, inevitable.
Dm7 — the ii chord. The melody turns upward F-G-A, reaching back toward the previous peak. Left hand shifts to D bass. Circle of fifths: Am → Dm (down a fifth).
G7 — the V chord. Another stepwise descent B-A-G-F. The tritone (B and F in the chord) creates tension that demands resolution. Left hand: G with F (root + b7).
Cmaj7 — the I chord. Resolution! The melody rises E-F-G, landing on the 5th. Left hand: C with B (root + maj7). The ii-V-I is complete. This is home.
Fmaj7 — the IV chord. The melody descends again A-G-F-E. The IV chord lifts the harmony — brighter, more open. Left hand: F with E (root + maj7).
Bm7b5 — the half-diminished chord. Beautiful tension. The melody rises D-E-F. Left hand: B with A (root + b7). This chord functions as ii in the key of Am.
E7 — the V of Am. The melody rises chromatically with G# (the leading tone to A). This is the emotional pivot — the E7 pulls hard toward Am. Left hand: E with D (root + b7).
Am — resolution of the secondary dominant. The melody lands on A and rests. A moment of pause before the second A section begins. Breathe here.
Am7 — second A section. Same descent C-B-A-G, but this time you know where it's going. The familiarity is the point — jazz standards reward the return.
Dm7 — slightly more rhythmic variation this time. The melody ornaments with eighth notes F-G before the A. The second pass through should feel more conversational.
G7 — the dominant again. Melody descends B-A-G and sustains. Holding the G builds anticipation for the resolution to come.
Cmaj7 — home again. The melody dips to D then returns to E. A small melodic sigh — contentment. The maj7 voicing (C with B in the bass) gives it that lush jazz color.
Dm7 — the melody ascends now! A-B-C-D, the widest upward motion in the piece. Building toward the final cadence. Energy rises.
G7 — the final dominant. The melody descends from the peak. C-B-A-G: the same intervals as measure 1, but now charged with the energy of the whole song behind them.
Cmaj7 — the final resolution begins. Melody ornaments E-F-G then descends to E and C (the tonic). Left hand outlines the full C chord. Landing gear down.
G7 to C — the final cadence. D resolves to C. The whole note lets the sound ring. Left hand: G7 walks down to C. You're home. The moon can wait.
